com.nbcuni.mps

Class MPSPageParameters

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.nbcuni.mps.MPSPageParameters

  • public class MPSPageParameters
extends Object
    Facilitates the population of MPS page request parameters.

    • Constructor Detail

      • MPSPageParameters

        public MPSPageParameters(@NonNull
                         android.content.Context context,
                         @NonNull
                         String path)
        Parameters:
        context - context.
        path - This is the unique identifier for this page/screen/content item. For websites, this is typically the uri path, however for devices driven by services data, this can be constructed - as long as it's logical and unique per page or content item. Do not include query string parameters in the path (eg: ?slide=1).

    • Method Detail

      • getPath

        @NonNull
public String getPath()
        Returns:
        path which is used for this MPSPageParameters object.

      • setType

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setType(@NonNull
                                          String value)
        Type is used to classify content into major display types (e.g. landing, listing, article, video, ecommerce, trailers, theater detail, blog post). This either comes directly from the cms or backend data object or usually corresponds to display templates or views. Content types often contain variations between ad placements on the page.
        Parameters:
        value - value to set as a type parameter.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setCat

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setCat(@NonNull
                                         String value)
        Pipe separated list of the category/site/app hierarchy for the current page/screen. This should come directly from the content if available, otherwise use the site map or navigational structure to construct this. This is the most important mps parameter as this is the primary data used to target ads and track metrics. You can pass in up to 5 levels, with the parent (most general) for e.g.:
        cat=ios|movies|coming_soon (Movies App), (News App) politics|elections|videos, (Cloud storage app) account|files|preview|photo section first, going in order.
        Parameters:
        value - category value.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setSubtype

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setSubtype(@NonNull
                                             String value)
        Further break down more generic content types. For example, if the content type is movie, you could have reviews within it. for e.g.: subtype=Reviews
        Parameters:
        value - subtype value.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setAdunits

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setAdunits(@NonNull
                                             String value)
        Available ad units in the current page or layout. The list of ad unit names (along with their sizes) for the entire site will be provided by the MPS team. Use pipes to separate multiple values.
        Parameters:
        value - ad units.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setTitle

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setTitle(@NonNull
                                           String value)
        Human readable Content, view or page title (e.g. node title). This should come from the cms or backend data object if possible.
        example: title=Anchorman 2 Movie Guide
        Parameters:
        value - title.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setContentId

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setContentId(@NonNull
                                               String value)
        This should be the content or page identifier which is usually the CMS or database id. If you do not have a back-end driven identifier, pass in nothing and MPS will generate one (based on hash of site+path). If you have multiple systems driving (like a video cms and a blog) the site that use the same id values, prefix the id with a letter for each source (like v123 and b123).
        Parameters:
        value - content id.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setEnvelope

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setEnvelope(@NonNull
                                              String value)
        Envelope is used in the cases where an individual page/view belongs to a parent set (or folder) – like if you’re viewing a page with a photo that actually belongs to a parent slideshow. In these cases, the parent content id (recommended) or the name of that parent/folder should be passed as the envelope.
        Parameters:
        value - envelope.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setIsContent

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setIsContent(boolean value)
        Use 1 for content level views (eg: Article, Slideshow, Video) and 0 for everything else (eg: Homepage, Landing, Content List, Account)
        Parameters:
        value - is content.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setPkgId

        public MPSPageParameters setPkgId(@NonNull
                                  String value)
        This is used for a data source to group of set of pages together into a single package. This can be alphanumeric characters only.
        Parameters:
        value - package id.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setReadonly

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setReadonly(boolean value)
        Setting this parameter to NSNumber(value: true) will cause the request to go into “read-only” mode which means that it will attempt to find the existing record using the site/path and read the existing data for the last full request made. It will ignore all existing parameters sent over. If there is no existing record for the site/path combination, then it will serve a fallback (default) response configured for the site.
        Parameters:
        value - readonly flag.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setCacheskip

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setCacheskip(boolean value)
        Set the CACHESKIP parameter. If it is set MPS will not use internal cache for this request.
        Parameters:
        value - true to skip cache, false otherwise.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • setPubDate

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters setPubDate(@NonNull
                                             Date date)
        Date when the content or page was published. This would come from the cms or the backend data object.
        Parameters:
        date - date when the content or page was published.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • addCag

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters addCag(@NonNull
                                         String group,
                                         @NonNull
                                         String value)
        Content Affinity Groups (CAGs) are used to pass in tag or keyword values to MPS, grouped by sets of terms. It is recommended to pass to all available keyword/tag sets into MPS programatically for each page based on content. Otherwise, you will have to build this manually. While you will get a list of required sets to send into MPS, if more data is available from the content, you should send those in because it will give ad sales/ops more to work with.
        Parameters:
        group - keyword.
        value - tag.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • addField

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters addField(@NonNull
                                           String group,
                                           @NonNull
                                           String value)
        Fields are used to define user session/instance specific terms to MPS. It follows the logic as CAGs (above). Things like login status, zip code, credit card type used are examples of this. While CAGs are items that come in from the backend data object or CMS, Fields are set situationally and can change between different users loading the same page; whereas CAGs are tag/keywords that are fixed values for every request it comes from the page/content data.
        Parameters:
        group - keyword.
        value - tag.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.

      • addAdditionalParam

        @NonNull
public MPSPageParameters addAdditionalParam(@NonNull
                                                     String key,
                                                     @NonNull
                                                     String value)
        Additional parameters for the request.
        Parameters:
        key - key for the request parameter.
        value - value for the request parameter.
        Returns:
        instance of MPSPageParameters.
